Thanks for joining me in this nonsense fanfic. Hope you enjoyed it!
Outside, the world raged against the end yet again. Inside, warm hearts found warm bodies and, for just a moment, their scars faded into the past.
The door closed behind the two. Muffled exertion resounded through the house. Unwashed dishes rested underneath a slowly dripping faucet. A small sword rested on a worn couch.
“Dishonorable things,” Leo said into Ogre’s ear before biting it softly.

“You might get dirty,” Ogre said, fumbling with their clothing and door. 
Leo broke away for only a moment, pawing at their own clothes. “I’m going to do much more than that.” 
Pressing through the threshold, holding close onto Leo, Ogre asked “Oh, yeah? What are you thinking?”

A chuckle broke their intensity, only for a moment, before Leo pulled Ogre’s face to theirs. 
A flurry of hands and gasps pulled them through their house, towards Ogre’s door. 
Half-panting, Ogre asked “You sure?” 
Leo only nodded.

Leo raised a hand from Orge’s shoulder and up to their face, remembering all the hard fights, all the blows struck. They ran their thumb along a scar they were pretty sure they caused. 
“I’m sorry,” they both said in unison.
Ogre moved their free hand to Leo’s scar-covered chest, feeling their shallow breath and beating heart. They smiled, remembering all the times this fool’s courage had brought them to blows.
Each of them had been rigid with anger and violence then, and the softness they found in each other in this moment was foreign. Ogre’s strong hands trembled and Leo’s stalwart eyes flittered.
The two stood for seconds that felt like hours, breathing in the anticipation of a forbidden desire. Their bodies had been pressed like this together before, in many battles over the years.

“Is that what you call my room?” Ogre said in a mock-offended tone. 
“If the used-up boot fits,” Leo said, pulling themselves closer.

Leo jolted slightly, surprised by the movement, before taking a slow breath in. 
“Is that so?” Ogre asked. 
“Where to?” 
“The trash heap,” Leo responded more harshly than they meant. They let their hands find themselves on Ogre’s sounders, their fingers lacing around Ogre’s spikes.

Leo, feeling Ogre’s heartbeat pressed against their own, responded. 
“Fine, I’ll take YOU out.” Ogre smiled deviously. 
“What, that’s not-,” Leo started. Ogre dropped their strong grip on Leo’s hand, choosing to wrap their other arm around Leo’s waist.

Ogre flashed through a hundred different responses, weighing the worst and best outcomes from this situation and decided that they had nothing more to lose. 
“Fine, but only if you take out the trash,” Ogre said.

“I have sensitive fur,” Leo responded. They struggled against their restraint, an act that only pushed their body closer to Ogre. “I noticed,” Orge said, seeming to breathe in Leo. “Let me go,” Leo repeated, softer this time.
Ogre chuckled. “Well we might be able to afford some if you didn’t spend all our Bits on expensive conditioner,” Ogre said, still holding their foe’s hand and blade aloft.
“Let me go,” Leo demanded, with fire in their eyes. “Only if you stop attacking me and help me clean up,” Ogre responded. “There’s not a strong enough soap in the world to scrub you clean,” Leo spat.

Both of them longed to ease their past scars but neither knew how without risking themselves to even more pain. 

Ogre felt the next swipe and reached up to grab the striking hand. Their strong grip immobilized Leo’s wrist, which felt oddly fragile within Ogre’s fingers.

It was a secret only to themselves that part of the frustration was a growing bond, an attraction born of the confines of their environment and a need for comfort. Neither would admit to it, except in late night half-dreams.
The rivals turned allies turned roommates could barely stand each other at the best of times, much less being confined together for so long.

Months and months of pent up frustration controlled their movements and responses now. The two had been forced into living together due to yet another round of digi-destined, world-ending, ultra-villain tomfoolery.
“Chill! I’ll take care of the dishes already!” Ogre shouted. “Dishonorable liar! That’s what you said last week!” Leo responded.

The blade cut through the air, narrowly missing Ogre’s shoulder. Leo let out a tremendous roar and took another swipe, and another, each one just barely missing their mark. It was impossible to know whether the strikes were genuine or simply meant to vent frustration.

"Fun fact!" Says Professor Kim, on day one of "Hazardous Engineering and You," a required course at Starfleet Academy.

"I'm not actually Harry Kim. I'm a spatial scission duplicate - so is Lieutenant Wilder, on the Huron. The real Harry Kim died on Stardate 49548.7."

"Either that," he says...

"Any questions before we get started?"

A tepid hand raises.

"We're you also... the rumor about the lizard stuff?"

Kim smiles knowingly. Every class asks.

"Yes, there are fates worse than multiversal death," he responds. "Just ask Tuvix."

The class murmurs questions he hopes they never answer.

Floating into his office chair, he stares at the frames on his wall. Photos, clippings, the smiling Bard. His veterinarian degree always stands out; a relic he earned.

The doorbell rings and a tepid “hello?” lingers in the air. Dr. Lich smiles.

“Well, no rest for the wicked.”

Dr. Lich turns off the lights to his small practice. He doesn’t need to sleep but it calms the animals in his care. He bids all of them a good night with a scratch of his bony fingers. His morbid face cracks a smile as a dog licks him. He treasures the love more than any gold.

*months later*
Dr. Lich: Fido here ate a cursed amulet, which didn’t set well with his belly or soul belly. *at dog* Did it Fido!? Who’s a little curse eater!?

Owner: Thank you so much! What do I owe you?

Lich: Nothing. Just have a talk with your kids about cursed artifacts.

Bard: So where does that leave you now?

Lich: I don’t know. I don’t want... this, but it is sort of all I can do now.

Bard: You know that’s not true. You defeated death itself; what if you applied that knowledge to pets?

Lich: Nobody wants a lich vet.

Bard: Nobody’s had one.

The box was small but magical. Each time something broken went in, it came out mostly repaired. Only minor deviations existed, based on the damage and how many times it had previously went in the box. But it was small, and so were the problems.

Three Abys'sal/humanoid Mimics inspired by @@2266's Spooky Synthfire Stories supplement! All three inspired by antagonists who met lets just say a less than untimely end... :) I really need to write up some backstories for them.
Art by myself!

They raised their hand, pulled on a finger, and snapped it sideways. The pain was searing but they were just a bit smaller now. Just a few more breaks, just a little more pain, and they could fit in the box. Besides, it would fix everything anyway. It was small but magical.

A small change, almost imperceptible really. It could still live, one could even hear the chirps beneath the new voice. But this was just a small bird, the box could barely fit the full broken human body. At least, as it currently was. What was a little more damage?

The bird was unlucky. It slammed against the window, dying before it hit ground. It fit nicely in the box, plenty of room. Hours later, it chirped to life. It stumbled at first, flying clumsily, but it flew all the same. It opened its beak, filling the air with quiet static.

The old mind wondered, intrigued at the brokenness of its vessel. A long life, full of joy and mistakes had left many things broken, badly repaired, and degrading. What would the box do to those things? It must fix them, or even make them better, so long as it wasn't abused.

A hammer eventually bending into a spiral was worth the money saved. A shoe growing metal soles was fine in moderation. The toaster being full of eyes was disturbing but easily replaced. The jacket began to sing, to cry, to beg to be saved from the fire it was thrown in.

Opening the door, he expected to see his child. He expected the full face of his memories, he expected the rotten corpse of his nightmares. There was nothing. Just black water, impossibly still and stagnant. It looked like a night without stars, a dream without end.
Thanks! I'm glad you made it over.

The next day, the rains stopped. A day later and the family went back to check. The house had collapsed, the foundations having crumpled. Much of it had run down, following the lazy river that had become their neighborhood. 

The father's body was never found.

Opening the door, he expected to see his child. He expected the full face of his memories, he expected the rotten corpse of his nightmares. There was nothing. Just black water, impossibly still and stagnant. It looked like a night without stars, a dream without end.

In the hall, he shuffled through the water to the cellar door. Just a hole in the ground covered by a small square door and a rug atop that. He could hear him clearly now, an angelic voice, his sweet child, crying and laughing and calling out love and fury. 

He moved the rug.

He heard the voice before he even left his car. His boots squelched in the soft mud of the yard. He could smell the rot and death and could hear the crying child in the claps of thunder. 

Just some clothing. Just the list. Just leave. Turn around. 

Run away. 

No. 

Not again.

The rain slowed and pretended as though it may stop. A sense of normality began to fill their little hotel room. The children complained of missing trinkets, the mother of fresh clothing for them all. They asked him to go back and get it all. They gave him a list and a hug.

They knew, they all knew. How could they not? He hurried them along. They had to leave, to get away from his terrible mistake. He could hear him all the time now, laughing and wailing in the flooded cellar. Everyone else had to know. They piled in the car and drove to drier land.

And the rains continued. The water began to reach through the floorboards. Green and sick and full of screaming. The man dreamt of his child, crawling through their house, half decomposed, splashing softly in the water, into his room, watching them sleep. He dreamt, he thought.

They could all smell it now, the rot all around them. His inability to face the truth, his snap decision and refusal of his mistake hung in the air. It stuck to them like sap, the rotting regret following them wherever they went. The children were teased, their mother distraught.

Beneath the house, there was no such respite. The father could hear water, moving around beneath their feet. Sloshing, and splashing, and moaning, and cries for help from a voice that could no longer be. "It was an accident!" he would scream into the floor. It wouldn't respond.

Days dragged into weeks. The smell grew, clouding the father's mind. He could hear him, feel him. Outside, the ground began to give up, allowing water to stack higher and higher on its surface. In the brief moments when the rain ceased, it took into itself as much as it could.

For days it drizzled and the man did not worry. His wife, his daughter, his youngest and only remaining son, all of them enjoyed the rain, content in knowing their brother was at the boarding school. None of them could feel him, rotting beneath them. None of them smelled him.

Unable to face the death of his son, incapable of living through the funeral, he buried him in the cellar. Damp walls and an unfinished floor made quick work of it. He didn't say goodbye, he simply closed off the room and called it a day. Then the rains came.

Spinning a few arcane words, they brought the plants back to life, gave them enhanced vitality, allowed them to bloom heavily. During the night, part of Jess died, and now, like the blossoming flowers before them, something else began to live.

When the sun crested the hills on the horizon, there was soft dirt covering their love like a blanket. The tears had dried, crusting over their cheeks. Jess had dug up the plants growing around the stone in their previous haste, now they bend down to pick them up.

They picked up the shovel and began putting it back in the grave. They cried, forceful and violent tears. More than once they had to stop, retching on the ground from the impact of it all. Years of pent up repression, years of denied mourning. It all came up that night.

Jess watched their love sink back into the grave. Their rotted face was serene. The shadows obscured it enough that Jess’ vision warped. They saw them, as they remembered, smiling, laughing, in love with life. This was a good place to leave, the last chance they may have at closure.

You messed up.

The door is gone. You sink slightly into the sand, attempting to pull yourself up you find you barely have the strength to breathe. The thing behind you clears its throat. The bugs skitter over your legs. 
The door is gone. 
The door is gone. 
The door is gone, soon you will be too.

Hard, sharp boots clack against the broken tile of the kitchen behind you. You came in here with a partner, a fool more desperate than you. It could be them, but you know it isn't. A long human shadow drapes across the sand tomb as whatever it is stares at you. You feel it's gaze on your neck.

But you messed up. The door ahead of you, the door containing the beast, it isn't there anymore. When did it vanish? You don't know. All the skittering in the sand, you can see it clearly now. Some sort of bug burrows under and in. You think to leave but then hear footsteps.

In the recursive house.

This was loop seven hundred or so. It was barely a house anymore. You sat in a pile of sand, bits of the "living room" skittering at the edges of your eyes. If you could make it past this... maybe you could get another chance at life.

You took the risk, coming into this part of the house again. You took the risk because you didn't in life. You were afraid to face your mistakes, and it ended you up here, dead in a meaningless limbo. There was nothing to do, nothing to gain, but a way out might exist.

You messed up.

Lying in the living room of the recursive house, knowing that this is the furthest you've made it before, you wait to hear the grumbling sounds of the beast that stopped you last time. For a long time, there is nothing. For even longer, there is also nothing.

Sure, sex is great, but have you ever truly lost someone? Have you ever felt the pang of their silence? Have you ever wept their name, tasting the bitter wrath of their absence? Have you given your all and lost all that mattered?

Sure, sex is great, but have you loved?

Have you ever set out to burn the life that denied you the only true thing you ever found, held their name in your mind as you began burning, cleansing, avenging, razing the universe to ash, hoping only that it may be reborn, and in the cosmic phoenix flames, they may again live?

Have you ever wept over the only one that truly mattered to you, your equal, your opposite, your sharpening steel, as you're congratulated by those who pushed you here, those who drove your hand to slay when all it ever wanted was to hold, to caress, to rest in theirs?

Have you ever cried out in anger, pushing down, firmly, quickly, finally, with your blade severing your ties to those possible pasts, screaming as you finished what you started and ended what they created within you, tears flowing as it dawns on you how meaningless it was?

Have you ever dreamed of their smile in your nightmares, given yourself over to their embrace even as you knew what fires it would ignite, both with yourselves and in the world, lost yourself in their eyes and wondered of day beyond this one, ones worth death, risks worth taking?

Sure, sex is great, but have you ever gone enemies to lovers to enemies, your sword pressed against their throat, wishing you could surrender your blade and press your lips there instead, begging any god that listens to wipe the fury and sadness from their eyes... and from yours?

Gonna be reposting some of my favorite stories. If you like them, please help boost them. Thanks!

#SoxStory

His time fighting dragons is over, his days as a father stretch before him. An adventure he chose but not one he planned for, not one he expected. He smiles, grabs the hand of the love that found him. She smiles too, eyes asking questions. He speaks quietly.

“You, mine now.”

It has been years since that first day when she was scoffed at by her family. Years since she started following him. Years since the birth of their first child. She has her own family now, full of love, full of surprises, full of pain, but all hers. All theirs.
But not all nights.

She nurtured the bond, like one might coax a timid animal. He was strong, brutish, silent, and sometimes arrogant, but she was his. She had taken to snuggling in his lap for warmth around the fire. He began to wrap his arms around her in return. Many nights they laid in silence, enjoying the fire.

He rejected her then, turning away with a scoff. But she would not be deterred. She followed, first from afar, then eventually near. Before long, the fool found himself outmatched, bleeding to death. She came to him then, patched his wounds, taking care of what was hers. She walked beside him after.

When she first found him, he was resplendent. Shining armor, huge stature, like a hero of legends. She grabbed at his thigh, terrified but resolute. He looked down at her, perplexed and frightened. She summoned all the courage within her goblin body and shouted. 
“You! Mine now!”
